paper_title.en: Numerical evaluation of maximum stress of a bulk superconductor in partial magnetization

description.en: Stresses in a bulk high-temperature superconductor (HTS) are numerically evaluated in magnetization process by field cooling. Shielding current distributions are obtained through macroscopic numerical simulation using Maxwell equations and critical state model. Stress distributions are obtained through numerical analysis using finite-element method. Differences between one-dimensional and axisymmetric three-dimensional solutions are discussed for the maximum stress distributions. Magnetic field profiles on the HTS are also discussed to estimate the shielding current distribution and maximum stress in partial magnetization.

paper_title.en: Numerical evaluations of maximum stresses in bulk superconductors

description.en: Stresses in bulk high-temperature superconductors (HTSs) are numerically evaluated during magnetization process by field cooling. Shielding current distributions are obtained through macroscopic numerical simulation using Maxwell equations and critical state model. Stress distributions are obtained through numerical analysis using finite-element method. Maximum stresses are evaluated from experimental results of destruction of the bulk HTS. Differences between one-dimensional and axisymmetric three-dimensional solutions are discussed for the stress distributions. Values and positions of the maximum stresses are affected by fixed conditions of the bulk HTS. (C) 2003 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Numerical evaluations of maximum stresses in bulk superconductors

description.en: Stresses in bulk high-temperature superconductors (HTSs) are numerically evaluated during magnetization process by field cooling. Values and positions of the maximum stresses are affected by fixed conditions of the bulk HTS. (C) 2003 Elsevier B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Maximum Stress in a Bulk HTS during Field-cooled Magnetization. Comparison of 1D Analytical Solution and 3D Axisymmetirc Numerical Solution.:Comparison of 1D Analytical Solution and 3D Axisymmetirc Numerical Solution

description.ja: A trapped field magnet is one application for melt-processed bulk high-Tc superconductors (HTSs). Evaluation of the maximum stress during magnetization is important from the viewpoint of the destruction of bulk HTS. Stresses in a bulk HTS are numerically evaluated during the magnetization process by field cooling. Shielding current distributions are obtained through macroscopic numerical simulation using Maxwell equations and the critical-state model. In the study of maximum stress, 3D axisymmetirc numerical solutions with open and fixed boundary conditions are compared with 1D analytical solutions. Analytical solutions are different from numerical solutions. It is shown that the evaluation of experimental results on the destruction of a bulk HTS will need numerical analysis.
description.en: A trapped field magnet is one application for melt-processed bulk high-Tc superconductors (HTSs). Evaluation of the maximum stress during magnetization is important from the viewpoint of the destruction of bulk HTS. Analytical solutions are different from numerical solutions. It is shown that the evaluation of experimental results on the destruction of a bulk HTS will need numerical analysis.

Numerical Evalutation of Strains of A Bulk High-T<sub>c</sub> Superconductor during Field-cooled Magnetization
Stress Distribution and Shape Factor of a Disk Trapped Field Magnet
Numerical evaluation of stresses of a bulk HTS in field-cooled magnetization

description.en: Stresses in a hulk high Tc superconductor (EFTS) are numerically evaluated, when the bulk HTS is fully magnetized with field-cooling. Numerical solutions for a cylindrical model are obtained by using the finite difference method. Differences between one- and two-dimensional solutions with, the Bean model are discussed through the analysis. The numerical evaluation is useful to discuss the stress distributions in the bulk HTS.

paper_title.en: Two-dimensional stress distributions in disk and ring high-T-c superconductors

description.en: Stresses in a bulk high-T-c superconductor (HTS) are numerically evaluated when the bulk HTS is fully magnetized by field cooling. The stress distributions for disk and ring models are obtained through numerical analyses with the finite-difference method. Differences between one- and two-dimensional solutions are examined using the Bean model in terms of the maximum tension stress and shear stress.

publication_name.en: JAPANESE JOURNAL OF APPLIED PHYSICS PART 1-REGULAR PAPERS SHORT NOTES & REVIEW PAPERS

paper_title.en: Evaluation of motion of a high-T-c superconducting thin film in microgravity experiments

description.en: Motion of a high-T-c superconducting (HTS) thin film was observed in microgravity experiments with a free fall drop shaft facility. The field-cooled thin film was suspended under a permanent magnet in the free fall experiments. When the magnet was rotated in microgravity, the thin film moved to a stable position where centrifugal force was balanced to restoring force caused by pinning of superconductor. The motion of the HTS thin film is numerically evaluated by using the frozen field model, which is based on an assumption that fluxoids are fixed at pinning points on the surface of the superconductor. The numerical evaluation is useful to explain the experimental results. (C) 1999 Elsevier Science B.V. All rights reserved.

paper_title.en: Evaluation of Magnetically levetated spinning top and levitation with a bulk high Tc superconductor
Macroscopic Numerical Evaluation oh Heat Generation in A Bulk High Tc Superconductor during Pulsed Field Magnetization(共著)
Levitation forces of a single-grained Y-Ba-Cu-O bulk superconductor of 48 mm in diameter

description.en: This paper describes the numerical and experimental superconducting levitation forces of a single-grained Y-Ba-Cu-O bulk superconductor of approximately 48 mm in diameter. The experimental levitation forces were measured by changing the magnet radius systematically. it was found experimentally that the levitation force shows a maximum when the magnet radius is slightly smaller than the superconductor radius. Comparison of the experimental and numerical levitation forces showed that even large bulk superconductors have a macroscopic value of J(c) as high as 2.0 x 10(4) A cm(-2), not much different from the microscopic value of J(c). (C) 1997 Elsevier Science Ltd.

paper_title.en: Numerical evaluation of levitation force of a stack with high Tc superconducting thin films

description.en: Hysteresis of the levitation force with a permanent magnet and a high Tc superconducting (HTS) thin film is discussed from calculated shielding current distribution with macroscopic numerical simulation code. Shielding current density of the thin film can be roughly estimated from the measurement of the levitation force. The levitation force of a stack with the thin films is also compared with that of bulk HTS. Numerical evaluation is useful to explain the experimental results and to discuss applications of the HTS thin film.

paper_title.ja: 微小重力下でのバルク高温超電導体の安定平衡特性(共著)
paper_title.en: Stable Equilibrium of bulk HTSC in microgravity

description.ja: Suspension and levitation of bulk high Tc superconductors (HTSCs) with a permanent magnet are observed in microgravity experiments. Different results from experiments on Earth have been observed for a sintered Y-Ba-Cu-O sample levitated above a ring shape magnet. However, a melt processed sample showed no difference in suspended and levitated positions for both on Earth and in the microgravity. The different motions between sintered and melt processed HTSCs in the microgravity can be explained by the difference in magnitude of the pinning force. It is shown that melt processed HTSCs for applications of suspension and levitation effects can be employed in space as on Earth.

paper_title.ja: 微小重力下でのバルク高温超電導体の安定平衡特性

description.ja: Suspension and levitation of bulk high Tc superconductors (HTSCs) with a permanent magnet are observed in microgravity experiments. It is shown that melt processed HTSCs for applications of suspension and levitation effects can be employed in space as on Earth.
